You’ll learn the divide-and-conquer design paradigm, with applications to fast sorting,

item.title: Burgers & Brew, K-theory, A-polynomial and Random Thoughts
item.description: Today we went to Burgers & Brew for lunch. Burgers & Brew is a very famous burgers restaurant in Davis. This is by far the greatest burgers I’ve never tried before. The beef inside tastes great! Far more better than the burgers in KFC or McDonald! I felt I had been too full after eating the hamburger! And it’s only $7 or so. more [caption id=“attachment_427” align=“aligncenter” width=“500”] Hamburger (@Burgers & Brew)[/caption]

item.title: Calculate PDOs using AXIOM / FriCAS
item.description: For years, the computation of Lax equations is a tedious and time-consuming task. For example, KdV equation has the following type of Lax equation: ```mathjax L_t = [A, L], ``` where ```mathjax L=\partial^2+u(x,t)```, (A=\partial^3+4u(x,t)\partial+2u_x). Having been a graduate student majoring in integrable systems for years, I always had to work on such kind of computations. It was frustrating. At that time, I was thinking of a way to speed up the computation with the power of computers.

item.title: Fiddle around with Lambert W function
item.description: Title: Date: [mathjax] These days I was fiddling around with one particular parameterization for Lambert curve. Although it was not that hard, I was happy that finally I made it clear. The problem is like this: a Lambert curve is a curve given by [C = {(z,w) ; | ; z = w e^w } \subset \mathbb{C}^* \times \mathbb{C}^*.] Note that the above equation defines (w) as an implicit function of (z).
